sen.j: 内山永久寺（うちやまえいきゅうじ）は奈良県天理市杣之内町にかつて存在した寺院である。
sen.e: Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple is a temple that once existed in Somanouchi-cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple is a temple that once existed in Somanouchi-cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple is a temple that once existed in Somanouchi-cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 日本最古の歴史の道といわれる山の辺の道沿いにある。
sen.e: The location of the temple is along the Yamanobe-no-michi, often referred as the oldest historic road of Japan.
The location of the temple is along the Yamanobe-no-michi, often referred to as the oldest historic road of Japan.
sen.cmt: referred to as に修正しました。
sen.e: The location of the temple is along the Yamanobe-no-michi, often referred to as the oldest historic road of Japan.

sen.j: 永久 (元号)年間（1113年-1118年）に鳥羽天皇の勅願により興福寺大乗院第2世頼実が創建し、第3世尋範に引き継がれて堂宇の整備が進められた。
sen.e: The temple was built during the period of Eikyu,1113 to 1118, by Yorizane, the second chief priest of Kofuku-ji Temple Daijo-in, at the imperial order of Emperor Toba, and later Jinban, the third chief priest took over the project to reorganize the buildings in the temple.
sen.cmt: 頼実の読み、時代的にも「よりざね」だと思うのですが確認が取れません。
sen.e: The temple was built during the Eikyu era (1113 - 1118) by Yorizane, the second chief priest of Kofuku-ji Temple Daijo-in, by imperial order of Emperor Toba, and afterward, the third chief priest Jinban took over the project to reorganize the buildings of the temple.
sen.cmt: 永久年間をthe Eikyu eraに修正しました。前置詞を修正しました（atをbyに、inをofに）
sen.e: The temple was built during the Eikyu era (1113 - 1118) by Yorizane, the second chief priest of Kofuku-ji Temple Daijo-in, by imperial order of Emperor Toba, and afterward, the third chief priest Jinban took over the project to reorganize the buildings of the temple.

sen.j: このため、当初より興福寺大乗院の末寺としての性格を備え、また本地垂迹説の流行と共に石上神宮の神宮寺としての性格を備えるようにもなった。
sen.e: The temple, taking part in Kofuku-ji Temple Daijo-in, from the beginning, due to the historical backdrop, began to gain a character of jingo-ji (a temple attached to a shrine), in the course of time, as the Honji Suijaku theory (that emphasizes the Shinto gods are manifestations of the heavenly buddhas and bodhisattvas) became popular, and eventually became one of the dominant temples with the backing of the power of Daijo-in, which was then one of the two power houses to control Kofuku-ji Temple.

Accordingly, the temple had a role as a branch temple of Kofuku-ji Temple Daijo-in from the beginning, and it also gradually gained a character of jingo-ji (a temple attached to a shrine) as the Honji Suijaku theory (that emphasizes the Shinto gods are manifestations of the heavenly buddhas and bodhisattvas) became popular.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処としました。文章の前半の意味がわかりにくいので書き直しました。
sen.e: Accordingly, the temple had a role as a branch temple of Kofuku-ji Temple Daijo-in from the beginning, and it also gradually gained a character of jingo-ji (a temple attached to a shrine) as the Honji Suijaku theory (that emphasizes the Shinto gods are manifestations of the heavenly buddhas and bodhisattvas) became popular.

sen.j: 興福寺を支配していた2大院家の一方である大乗院の権威を背景として、室町期には絶大なる勢力を誇った。
sen.e: Eventually it became a dominant temple supported by the power of Daijo-in, which was then one of the two major powerful houses to control Kofuku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処としました。「became one of the dominant temples with the backing of the power of Daijo-in」を「 became a dominant temple supported by the power of Daijo-i」としました。
sen.e: Eventually it became a dominant temple supported by the power of Daijo-in, which was then one of the two major powerful houses to control Kofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 『太平記』によると延元元年・建武 (日本)3年（1336年）には後醍醐天皇が一時ここに身を隠したと伝えられ、「萱御所跡」という旧跡が残された。
sen.e: According to the "Taiheiki", a Japanese historical epic, Emperor Godaigo hided himself in the temple briefly in 1336, and because of this episode the site is preserved as the former Kaya Palace, a historic site that indicates an emperor once resided.

According to "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace), Emperor Godaigo secretly stayed at the temple for a short time in 1336, and the site is preserved as the former Kaya Palace, a historic site that indicates an emperor once resided, because of this episode.
sen.cmt: 太平記の英語名を用語集より追加しました。「身を隠した」の表現を変更しました。「because of this episode」の挿入位置を変更しました。
sen.e: According to "Taiheiki" (The Record of the Great Peace), Emperor Godaigo secretly stayed at the temple for a short time in 1336, and the site is preserved as the former Kaya Palace, a historic site that indicates an emperor once resided, because of this episode.

sen.j: かつては浄土式回遊庭園を中心に、本堂、灌頂堂、八角多宝塔、三重塔など最盛期には50以上の堂塔が並ぶ大伽藍を誇り、江戸時代には971石の朱印地を与えられていた。
sen.e: Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple, at its best times, was a huge monastery consisting of more than 50 of buildings, including the hondo (main hal), the kanchodo (hall of esoteric consecration), octagonal tahoto pagoda (multi-treasure pagoda), and three-story pagoda, placing a stroll garden styled by the Jodo (Pure Land) sect of Buddhism at its center, and was later granted a feudal estate of 971 koku (a unit to measure harvest quantity) by the Edo shogunate.

Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple, at its best times, was a huge monastery consisting of more than 50 buildings including the hondo (main hall), a kanchodo (hall of esoteric consecration), an octagonal tahoto pagoda (multi-treasure pagoda), and a three-story pagoda, and these buildings were placed around a stroll garden in the style of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect of Buddhism.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処としました。「more than 50 of buildings」からofを削除、hallのスペルミスの訂正、冠詞の追加を行いました。
sen.e: Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple, at its best times, was a huge monastery consisting of more than 50 buildings including the hondo (main hall), a kanchodo (hall of esoteric consecration), an octagonal tahoto pagoda (multi-treasure pagoda), and a three-story pagoda, and these buildings were placed around a stroll garden in the style of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect of Buddhism.

sen.j: なおこの時代に上乗院が寺主となって興福寺の支配下から離れ、真言宗寺院となっている。
sen.e: In this period, Jojo-in took over the owner of the temple and the temple separated itself from the control of Kofuku-ji Temple to be a temple belonging to the Shingon sect.
In this period, Jojo-in became the owner of the temple, and the temple became a Shingon sect temple, departing from the control of Kofuku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: took overをbecameに変更、文章の後半を書き換えました。
sen.e: In this period, Jojo-in became the owner of the temple, and the temple became a Shingon sect temple, departing from the control of Kofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 大和では東大寺・興福寺・法隆寺に次ぐ待遇を受ける大寺であり、その規模の大きさと伽藍の壮麗さから、江戸時代には「西の日光」とも呼び習わされた。
sen.e: The temple was the fourth biggest temple in Yamato (roughly current Nara Prefecture), after Todai-ji, Kofuku-ji, and Horyu-ji, and was once called as "Nikko in the West" due to its huge scale and magnificent buildings of the temple.

The temple was the fourth biggest temple in Yamato (roughly current Nara Prefecture), after Todai-ji Temple, Kofuku-ji Temple, and Horyu-ji Temple, and they were once called as "Nikko in the West" due to its huge scale and magnificent buildings of the temple.
sen.cmt: 寺の英名にそれぞれ「Temple」を追加、後半の節に主語を追加しました。
sen.e: The temple was the fourth biggest temple in Yamato (roughly current Nara Prefecture), after Todai-ji Temple, Kofuku-ji Temple, and Horyu-ji Temple, and they were once called as 'Nikko in the West' due to its huge scale and magnificent buildings of the temple.

sen.j: また、当寺は修験道当山派との関わりも深く、当山三十六正大先達衆を構成する一寺として、重要な役割を果たしており、これは修験道が明治の神仏分離令で禁止された結果、続く廃仏毀釈で当寺が致命的な打撃を被る一因となった。
sen.e: The temple also deeply involved in Tozan-ha school of Shugendo (Japanese ascetic and shamanistic practice in mountainous sites), playing an important role as one of the Tozan-sanjuroku-daisendatsushu (Tozan school's thirty-six great leaders), and this became one of the major reasons why the temple had to be damaged fatally at the beginning of the Meiji period, when Shugendo was forbidden by the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism, which contributed the anti-Buddhist movement in the next phase.
sen.cmt: 当山三十六正大先達衆 定訳らしいものがみあたりません。内容から、Tozan school's thirty-six great leadersとしておきました。
sen.e: The temple also deeply involved in Tozan-ha school of Shugendo (Japanese ascetic and shamanistic practice in mountainous sites), playing an important role as one of the Tozan-sanjuroku-daisendatsushu (Tozan school's thirty-six great leaders), and this became one of the major reasons why the temple had to be damaged fatally at the beginning of the Meiji period, when Shugendo was forbidden by the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism, which contributed the anti-Buddhist movement in the next phase.

The temple also deeply involved in Tozan-ha school of Shugendo (Japanese ascetic and shamanistic practice in mountainous sites), playing an important role as one of the Tozan-sanjuroku-daisendatsushu (Tozan school's thirty-six great leaders), and this became one of the major reasons why the temple had to be damaged fatally at the beginning of the Meiji period, when Shugendo was forbidden by the Ordinance Distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism, which contributed the anti-Buddhist movement in the next phase.

sen.j: 明治に入って廃仏毀釈の嵐の中で寺領を没収され、経営基盤を奪われた当寺は廃寺となって僧侶は還俗し、石上神宮の神官となった。
sen.e: In the turmoil of the anti-Buddhist movement, the temple lost the foundation to manage, only to turn out to be ruined, making its priest return to secular life or to Shinto priests.

In the turmoil of the anti-Buddhist movement, the temple became extinct because they lost their territories and their fiscal foundation, and priests of this temple had to return to secular life or become Shinto priests of Isonokami-jingu Shrine.
sen.cmt: 全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: In the turmoil of the anti-Buddhist movement, the temple became extinct because they lost their territories and their fiscal foundation, and priests of this temple had to return to secular life or become Shinto priests of Isonokami-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 更に、壮麗を極めた堂宇や什宝はことごとく徹底した破壊と略取の対象となった。
sen.e: In addition, the temple's magnificent buildings and treasures were completely looted and destroyed.
In addition, the temple's magnificent buildings and treasures were completely looted and destroyed.
In addition, the temple's magnificent buildings and treasures were completely looted and destroyed.

sen.j: この際流出した仏像・仏画・経典等はいずれも製作当時の工芸技術の精華と言うべき優品揃いであったことが知られている。
sen.e: It is known that all those treasures, including statues and images of Buddha, and Buddhist scriptures, were remarkable pieces of work that had shown the essence of craftsmanship of the time of each production.

It is known that all those treasures including statues, images of Buddha, and Buddhist scriptures, were remarkable pieces of work that had shown the essence of craftsmanship of the time of each production.
sen.cmt: 余分なカンマの削除、余分なandの削除をおこないました。
sen.e: It is known that all those treasures including statues, images of Buddha, and Buddhist scriptures, were remarkable pieces of work that had shown the essence of craftsmanship of the time of each production.

sen.j: 海外に流出した宝物の内、ベルリン民俗学博物館が購入した真然筆と伝えられる真言八祖像などは第二次世界大戦末期のベルリン攻防戦で烏有に帰した。
sen.e: Some of treasures were bought overseas, and, among others, a painting of Shingon-hasso-zo (painting of the eight founders of the Shingon), attributed to Shinnen, was bought by the Ehnological Museum of Berlin only to cease to exist because of the Battle of Berlin, at the very end of the second world war.

Some of treasures were taken away to foreign countries, and among such treasures, a painting of Shingon-hasso-zo (painting of the eight founders of the Shingon sect), which was attributed to Shinnen, was bought by the Ehnological Museum of Berlin, but it was reduced to ashes because of the Battle of Berlin, at the very end of World War II.
sen.cmt: 「海外に流出」の表現を変更、途中の挿入句の修正、「烏有に帰した」の表現の変更、「第二次世界大戦」の訂正。
sen.e: Some of treasures were taken away to foreign countries, and among such treasures, a painting of Shingon-hasso-zo (painting of the eight founders of the Shingon sect), which was attributed to Shinnen, was bought by the Ehnological Museum of Berlin, but it was reduced to ashes because of the Battle of Berlin, at the very end of World War II.

sen.j: しかし、日本国内に残存した宝物の大半が、現在重要文化財・国宝指定を受けていることは、当寺の得ていた富がいかに巨大であったかを物語るものである。
sen.e: However, the fact many of the treasures that survived the time and kept in Japan are now designated as Important Cultural Properties or National Treasures just indicates how enormous the wealth the temple had.

However, the fact that many of the treasures that survived the time and kept in Japan are now designated as Important Cultural Properties or National Treasures just indicates how enormous the wealth the temple had was.
sen.cmt: factの後にthatを挿入、how～句に動詞を挿入。
sen.e: However, the fact that many of the treasures that survived the time and kept in Japan are now designated as Important Cultural Properties or National Treasures just indicates how enormous the wealth the temple had was.

sen.j: 現在では当寺の敷地の大半は農地となり、本堂池と萱御所跡の碑が往時をしのぶだけである。
sen.e: Now, the majority of the area the temple once existed was converted into farmlands, only two things, a pond by which the hondo (mail hall) stood, and a monument indicating the former Kaya Place, are suggesting the bygone days.
Most of the temple's site is now used as farmlands, and only two things, a pond by which the hondo (mail hall) stood, and a monument indicating the former Kaya Place, are suggesting the bygone days.
sen.cmt: 「現在では当寺の敷地の大半は農地となり」の箇所を書き換えました。
sen.e: Most of the temple's site is now used as farmlands, and only two things, a pond by which the hondo (mail hall) stood, and a monument indicating the former Kaya Place, are suggesting the bygone days.

tit.j: 内山永久寺から流出した文化財
tit.e: Cultural properties scattered from Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple
Cultural Properties Scattered from Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple
Cultural Properties Scattered from Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple

sen.j: 出雲建雄神社（いずもたけおじんじゃ）割拝殿（国宝） 奈良県天理市・石上神宮（いそのかみじんぐう）所有
sen.e: Wari-Haiden (literally, divided worship hall) of Izumo Takeo-jinja Shrine, National Treasure, held by Isonokami-jingu Shrine, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture
Wari-Haiden (literally, divided worship hall) of Izumo Takeo-jinja Shrine, National Treasure, held by Isonokami-jingu Shrine in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture
sen.cmt: Shrineと Tenri Cityの間にinを挿入しました。
sen.e: Wari-Haiden (literally, divided worship hall) of Izumo Takeo-jinja Shrine, National Treasure, held by Isonokami-jingu Shrine in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture

sen.j: もと内山永久寺鎮守の住吉神社拝殿。
sen.e: This was used as Haiden, a hall for worship of a Shinto shrine, of Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, a former tutelary shrine for Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple.
This was used as Haiden, a hall for worship of a Shinto shrine, of Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, a former tutelary shrine for Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple.
This was used as Haiden, a hall for worship of a Shinto shrine, of Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, a former tutelary shrine for Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 廃仏毀釈の際に難を逃れたものを1914年現在地に移築。
sen.e: It survived the anti-Buddhism movement at the beginning of the Meiji period, and was moved to the current location in 1914.
It survived the anti-Buddhism movement at the beginning of the Meiji period, and was moved to the current location in 1914.
It survived the anti-Buddhism movement at the beginning of the Meiji period, and was moved to the current location in 1914.

sen.j: 現在は石上神宮摂社の出雲建雄神社の拝殿となっている。
sen.e: Currently, it is used as the Haiden to Izumo Takeo-jinja Shrine, a sessha (auxiliary shrine) of Isonokami-jingu Shrine.
Currently, it is used as the Haiden to Izumo Takeo-jinja Shrine, a sessha (auxiliary shrine) of Isonokami-jingu Shrine.
Currently, it is used as the Haiden to Izumo Takeo-jinja Shrine, a sessha (auxiliary shrine) of Isonokami-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 両部大経感得図（国宝） 大阪市・藤田美術館蔵
sen.e: Ryobu taikyo kantokuzu (paintings of the Spiritual Reception of the Two Great Sutras), National Treasure, held by Fujita Museum of Art, Osaka City
Ryobu taikyo kantokuzu (paintings of the Spiritual Reception of the Two Great Sutras), National Treasure, held by Fujita Museum of Art in Osaka City
sen.cmt: Osaka Cityの前にinを挿入しました。
sen.e: Ryobu taikyo kantokuzu (paintings of the Spiritual Reception of the Two Great Sutras), National Treasure, held by Fujita Museum of Art in Osaka City

sen.j: 木造持国天・多聞天立像（重要文化財） 奈良市・ 東大寺蔵（奈良国立博物館寄託）
sen.e: Wooden statues of Jikokuten and Tamonten, Important Cultural Asset, owned by Todai-ji Temple, Nara City (deposited to Nara National Museum)
Wooden statues of Jikokuten and Tamonten, Important Cultural Asset, owned by Todai-ji Temple in Nara City (deposited to Nara National Museum)
sen.cmt: Nara Cityの前にinを挿入しました。
sen.e: Wooden statues of Jikokuten and Tamonten, Important Cultural Asset, owned by Todai-ji Temple in Nara City (deposited to Nara National Museum)

sen.j: 木造四天王眷属立像（重要文化財） 東京国立博物館、静嘉堂文庫、MOA美術館の3か所に分かれて所蔵。
sen.e: Wooden Shitenno Kenzoku Ritsuzo (statues of the four heavenly kings and followers), Important Cultural Property, held by Tokyo National Museum, Seikado Bunko Art Museum and MOA Museum of Art.
Wooden Shitenno Kenzoku Ritsuzo (statues of the four heavenly kings and followers), Important Cultural Property, held by Tokyo National Museum, Seikado Bunko Art Museum and MOA Museum of Art.
Wooden Shitenno Kenzoku Ritsuzo (statues of the four heavenly kings and followers), Important Cultural Property, held by Tokyo National Museum, Seikado Bunko Art Museum and MOA Museum of Art.

sen.j: 仏師康円（運慶の孫）作。
sen.e: Sculpted by Busshi Koen, a grandson of Unkei (Busshi is a sculptor specializing in Buddha statues)
Sculpted by Busshi Koen, a grandson of Unkei (Busshi is a sculptor specializing in Buddha statues)
Sculpted by Busshi Koen, a grandson of Unkei (Busshi is a sculptor specializing in Buddha statues)

sen.j: 四天王の眷属の彫像として稀有のもの。
sen.e: This is a rare statue of parivara of the four heavenly kings.
This is a rare statue of parivara of the four heavenly kings.
This is a rare statue of parivara of the four heavenly kings.

sen.j: 木造不動明王及び八大童子像（重要文化財） 東京都・世田谷山観音寺蔵
sen.e: Wooden statue of Fudomyoo and Hachidai Doji, Important Cultural Property, held by Setagayasan Kannon-ji Temple, Tokyo
Wooden statue of Fudomyoo and Hachidai Doji, Important Cultural Property, held by Setagayasan Kannon-ji Temple in Tokyo
sen.cmt: Tokyoの前にinを挿入しました。
sen.e: Wooden statue of Fudomyoo and Hachidai Doji, Important Cultural Property, held by Setagayasan Kannon-ji Temple in Tokyo

sen.j: 仏師康円作。
sen.e: Sculpted by Busshi Koen
Sculpted by Busshi Koen
Sculpted by Busshi Koen

sen.j: 新潟県の石油王・中野忠太郎の所蔵を経て現所有者へ移動。
sen.e: The statue was once owned by Chutaro Nakano, an oil baron of Nigata, and was later transferred to the current owner.
The statue was once owned by Chutaro NAKANO, an oil baron who lived in Nigata Prefecture, and was later transferred to the current owner.
sen.cmt: 名字（中野）を大文字に、「新潟県の」をwho lived in Nigata Prefectureに変更しました。
sen.e: The statue was once owned by Chutaro NAKANO, an oil baron who lived in Nigata Prefecture, and was later transferred to the current owner.

sen.j: 真言八祖行状図（重要文化財） 出光美術館蔵
sen.e: Shingon Hasso Gyojo-Zu Picture (painting of the behavior of the eight founders of Shingon), Important Cultural Property, held by Idemitsu Museum of Arts
Shingon Hasso Gyojo-Zu Picture (painting of the behavior of the eight founders of Shingon), Important Cultural Property, held by Idemitsu Museum of Arts
Shingon Hasso Gyojo-Zu Picture (painting of the behavior of the eight founders of Shingon), Important Cultural Property, held by Idemitsu Museum of Arts

sen.j: 内山永久寺真言堂の障子絵であったと考証されている。
sen.e: This is thought to be one of the Shoji-e (paintings on shoji paper sliding-door or Fusuma) of the Shingondo (Shingon hall) of Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple.
This is thought to be one of the Shoji-e (paintings on shoji paper sliding-door or Fusuma) of the Shingondo (Shingon hall) of Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple.
This is thought to be one of the Shoji-e (paintings on shoji paper sliding-door or Fusuma) of the Shingondo (Shingon hall) of Uchiyama-Eikyu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 近畿日本鉄道天理線天理駅から奈良交通バス桜井駅行きで6分。
sen.e: From Kintetsu Tenri Station, take a Nara Kotsu Bus bound for Sakurai Station for 6 minutes. Get off at Magata bus stop and walk for 25 minutes.
From Kintetsu Tenri Station, take a six-minute ride on a Nara Kotsu Bus bound for Sakurai Station.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処セル内に2つの文章が入っていたので分割しました。「6分」の表現と位置を変更。
sen.e: From Kintetsu Tenri Station, take a six-minute ride on a Nara Kotsu Bus bound for Sakurai Station.

sen.j: 勾田下車、徒歩25分
sen.e: Get off at Magata bus stop and walk for 25 minutes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Get off at Magata bus stop and walk for 25 minutes.
